None
country:
None
text:
So happy so many people like this recipe. Just to address a couple of issues some people are having:

When making the recipe I used ground turkey which was a mixture of white and dark meat. This not only helped add flavor but it also added moisture that helped it to not become crumbly. Adding an extra egg is also a great way to bind it even more and hey! Extra protein!

Secondly, this meatloaf is meant to be free-formed on a flat pan. Ground turkey and ground beef cook two different ways.  Beef tends to give off a considerable amount of fat and a little juice making it ok (although not at all healthy) to cook it in a loaf pan soaking in its oils.... turkey and chicken on the other hand give off a lot of moisture and very little fat, so basically when you cook it in a loaf pan it is steaming and soaking in turkey water, making for a mushy fall-aparty (yes i made that word up) loaf.

I hope this helps some of the future folk who make this recipe.

~drew

text:
This recipe is a family favorite! I love quinoa and I'm constantly trying to find different ways to use it.   I do a couple different things with this recipe, just for my own personal taste.  -I leave out the hot sauce, since I have 2 small children, but I add some on top of my serving.  -I add 1 cup of grated cheese to the meatloaf, I like the extra flavor and it moistens it up a bit.  -I haven't yet tried the topping for this recipe because I love my old one too much. 1/4 c. brown sugar, 1/4 c. ketchup, 1 Tbsp Mustard and a few splashes of Worchestershire.  Try this recipe, you won't be disappointed!

text:
Absolutely delicious! The whole family really enjoyed this dish. I didn’t add any hot sauce because I wanted this dish to be “kid friendly”, so I did add 1 1/2-Tbsp of BBQ sauce and a dash of liquid smoke flavoring instead. I also had to add 1/3 cup of Panko breadcrumbs because I thought it needed to be a little firmer. For the toping I made my own recipe: ¼ cup ketchup, 1 Tbsp brown sugar, 2 tsp Dijon mustard and 2 dashes liquid smoke flavoring. Thanks for sharing this great recipe Drew!!!
10/04/11: Drew, I was just printing your recipe to make it again and noticed that you are in Pembroke Pines, FL. Can't believe we are so close! I'm just all the way East from you, as I live very close to the beach. I make this recipe quite often, we all love it. Thanks again!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is great and easy just as written.  The hot sauce makes this so tasty.  We eat a lot of quinoa so I make a big batch and freeze it in 4oz servings.  I use it just like I would "instant rice".  Since I'm cooking for two, I made 4 loaves shaped like footballs.  We eat two and  have  an extra meal for later.  Like the quinoa, this freezes really well.  Just remember to adjust your cooking time.  I started checking after a half hour with a thermometer.  I also made the topping a little runny.  I made little troughs in the loaves, about the size of a pencil, and poured the topping in those.  The sauce seeped into the meat and wow!  Think I will double the topping next time!    One more thought.  Try baking the meatlof in a cupcake pan.  This way you have little kid size portions.  Thanks for the recipe, Drew, it will go on our table many a time.

text:
Yum! Definitely a good alternative to traditional meatloaf and I always love quinoa. Instead of the brown sugar glaze, I did a ketchup & Worcestershire glaze with a smidge of sriracha because my family doesn't have a sweet tooth (and I don't usually keep sugar in the house). I also doubled the quinoa because I am always trying to stretch a recipe as far as I can, it didn't make the recipe any less moist. My 7 year olds and my husband both LOVED it. Served with roasted sweet potatoes & Brussels sprouts.

text:
I enjoyed this recipe a lot.  There is a bit of a kick to it due to the hot sauce; it's not tongue-searing hot by any means, but it's a consideration if you're feeding it to kids.  I thought the 1 egg was enough to bind the meatloaf mixture, but it is important that you let the meatloaf stand at least 10 minutes before cutting it up so that it has the best chance of holding its shape when sliced (which was done easily with a serrated knife).  All in all, it was one of the better recipes for meatloaf that I cooked up, and I think I'll keep it in the dinner rotation.

text:
Wow, this was really good!  What an interesting way to make a gluten-free meatloaf.  I added green onion along with the regular onion and baked my meatloaf in individual silicon muffin trays since to me the most annoying thing about meatloaf is how long it takes to bake all the way through.  With the muffin sizes, overall bake time was only about 30 minutes instead of 50 and they just popped right out.  Great recipe, thanks for sharing!

text:
If I could give this 10 stars I would--This is my family's new favorite meatloaf!  You can't go wrong by using whole grain instead of breadcrumbs.  The quinoa gave this a fabulous bite and texture, and it is seasoned extremely well.  I added chives from the garden for color, and next time, will probably top it with BBQ sauce.  **It's really important to not use ground turkey breast because it will turn out too dry and colorless.  A winner for sure!  Thanks for sharing!

text:
This is an excellent recipe. I've made it a number of times using turkey, or ground chicken breast, I even tried half turkey/half tofu and it was excellent. Love quinoa instead of breadcrumbs (which I can't have). I used ketchup instead of tomato paste and tabasco sauce for heat. Instead of egg I used chia seeds in water (as a replacer) and added some ground flaxseeds to the mix too. Thanks Drew !

lAt first, I was afraid to try this because I love my old "bread crumb" meatloaf, but this was absolutely perfect and will become our "fave meatloaf recipe" now.      Just could not believe how good it was    I bought the quinoa for the first time organic and then read somewhere on line that you need to soak it and rinse it because there is a coating on it that can be bitter tasting and also have a laxative effect, so trust me we soaked the quinoa first for a couple hours and then rinsed it over and over before cooking it.    Turned out perfect.  INCREDIBLE RECIPE!!!!!  THANK YOU SO MUCH FOR SHARING THIS!!!!!   LOVE Allrecipes and since retiring this is my favorite internet site!!!

Display Name:
Yumyum ^^

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614254.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Tasty + very easy to make + healthy = 5 stars!  Made the following changes: 2 packages of ground chicken (~20 oz total) because store didn't have turkey; 1/2 cup quinoa boiled in 1 cup chicken stock; 2 eggs; 2 tbsp homemade bbq sauce instead of hot pepper sauce; 1 tbsp ketchup instead of tomato paste; halved the salt and pepper measurements; topped with bbq sauce instead of brown sugar mixture.  I prepped everything (in about 20 minutes) before beach vball and refrigerated the mixture.  When I came home, I preheated the oven to 350F, sprayed a foiled lined baking sheet with PAM, shaped the mixture into a flattish rectangular loaf and topped with bbq sauce, then popped in the oven for 50 minutes.  We ate it with mashed potatoes, yum!  Makes 4 generous servings.  I love how easy it is to prep and the great taste!  Will definitely make again.

text:
I put off making this recipe as I just never have any quinoa in the house, but this past weekend I noticed a box of it at the grocery store and added it to my cart.  I am so happy that I did!  This recipe was incredibly moist and flavorful and perfectly seasoned.  At my house it made enough for 4 adult and 2 toddler sized portions (only because I filled up on veggies in order to keep myself from eating seconds ... and thirds).  Using a nutritional powerhouse like quinoa in place of breadcrumbs makes me feel great about serving this to my family.  I plan to make a few more batches this weekend to stock in my deep freeze for lazy dinners in the near future :)

text:
I realy liked it...the texture was great, and it just is a healthier variation to the classic ground beef meatloaf.  When it was almost done, on day 2, I sliced it up and made a sandwich!!  One thing I realized I didn't have when I was preparing it was the tomato paste, so I used ketchup...the tabasco in this recipe realy gives this a balanced taste.  Ground turkey on it's own can be bland in comparison to ground beef, so the tabasco and  worcestershire is a must in this recipe.  I scaled down the hot sauce abit...I was scared it would be too spicy.  I also added about 2/3 cup of homemade bread crumbs.  Overall, this is nice, low in fat, lots of flavour, and I'll be making it often!!

Display Name:
Michelle Roth-Kiva
isPro:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2689406.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wowie! This is a DARN good meatloaf!!! I am happy to have FINALLY found a DECENT turkey loaf recipe (I've tried many...). My only reason for giving this 4 *'s is b/c my "picky" hubby wasn't a fan. I don't consider myself a health nut, but am trying to adapt to that lifestyle. I've heard of quinoa before, but never tried it. And, although I seem to like it, I think I prefer breadcrumbs instead. I too cooked my quinoa in (chicken) broth to enhance its flavor. My only other changes were to add ~ 3/4 c. shredded reduced-fat cheddar cheese & substitute chile sauce for hot sauce (I was afraid my loaf would be too spicy otherwise). I will NOT add cheese next time (there WILL be a next time!) since most of it oozed out anyways. I assembled my "loaf" yesterday, refrigerated it overnite & then had my hubby put it in the oven when he got home from work so that dinner would be ready when I got home. NOTE: I purchased a box of Roland brand quinoa which was specifically labeled as having been "pre-washed." This step removes the naturally occurring bitter coating, saponin. Served w/ mashed sweet potatoes, garlic green beans & dinner rolls, this was a FANTASTIC MEAL! Other than subbing breadcrumbs for quinoa, omitting the glaze (hubby didn't like THAT either argh!!!) & serving w/ gravy instead, I wouldn't change a thing about this. Thanks SO much for sharing, Drew! :-)

text:
This is the best meatloaf I've ever had. Not to mention a great way to get quinoa in my family's diet. I left out the sugar because you really don't need it. Why ruin a perfectly healthy meatloaf with sugar? I "double" it by just making it with 2lbs of ground turkey and double everything else too. My kids and husband LOVE it and they are stingy with compliments. I also put them on one baking pan lined with wax paper and make them into 6-7 individual loafs. Makes it quicker to cook and less like one huge blob.

city:

country:

text:
LOVE this one! I made it exactly as written as I usually try to do the first time I try something--this one hits the mark.  Note: Always rinse quinoa before using to eliminate the bitter taste. I used Frank's Red Hot Sauce for the hot sauce ingredient.  Because of the 2 Tbs. used, we found this to have a bit of a kick so keep that in mind if you make this. The topping was quite liquid so I found it impossible to "paste" the top of the loaf--more like pouring it over slowly to ensure that it absorbs a bit before baking.  My loaf was a bit salty so I will cut back on salt.  Each hot sauce probably has a different amount of salt so other cooks may not have this problem.  This one is going into "the rotation" for sure!  Thanks, Drew!

text:
Best meatloaf recipe I've tried.  Adding the quinoa gives the dish a nice nutty flavor!  Using quinoa instead of bread crumbs also gives the dish a more pleasant texture.  Instead of a brick-like texture, the servings have a lighter consistency.  Having the added bonus of using a complete protein grain such as quinoa is a definite plus for those looking for healthy recipes.  I will definitely make this recipe many more times.

text:
This meatloaf is AMAZING! It has such a great flavor. I added a few squirts of sriracha as the "hot pepper sauce" and it gave it a great kick! Next time I will probably add more (red) quinoa just because it is so nutritious and gives a great texture. I was a little surprised by how small this meatloaf was. I cooked the loaf in a glass bread loaf dish and when I took it out of the oven, it had shrunk around the edges. It was perfect for my boyfriend and I and we even had leftovers, but if you're cooking for a larger family, you may want to double the recipe! And btw - the loaf dish was perfect because it was able to cook in it's own juiciness!

country:
None
text:
I am not a fan of regular meatloaf, but this was FANTASTIC! I LOVED the texture of the ground meat and quinoa and felt the quinoa added a nice flavour. I think where this recipe goes wrong is not mentioning what TYPE of hot pepper sauce people should use. I read some reviews that thought the 'hot sauce' was overpowering, some that called the recipe bland. There are so many types of hot pepper sauce with differing flavour profiles, I'd like to know what type/brand the recipe's author intended. The first time I made this, I used a Thai sweet garlic chilli sauce, as a review recommended and it was PERFECT!! The second time I tried a Jamaican hot pepper sauce and it was too bland. I would never try a tablespoon of tabasco because I think that WOULD overwhelm the recipe, but I might try 1/2 TBS. This is a fantastic recipe and I intend to keep experimenting  with the different hot pepper sauces, but I'll double the recipe and make one with the sweet garlic chilli sauce.

userID:

Display Name:
Amy Evans

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2178888.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was awesome! I doubled all the ingredients for a 48 oz package of ground turkey. I did make a few changes. I didn't have tomato paste so I used equal parts ketchup. I also substituted equal parts BBQ sauce for the hot sauce to keep it from being spicy for the little one. I doubled the number of eggs (in this case, I used 4) to keep it from being too dry. I reduced the salt to 2 tsp and I felt it was plenty salty. My substitutions of ketchup and BBQ sauce may have contributed to the saltiness. Also, I used sea salt which tends to be "saltier". I may reduce it even more next time. As recommended, I cooked it on a cookie sheet covered with aluminum foil. This made clean-up pretty easy and kept the turkey from cooking in its own liquid and becoming soggy. Finally, I formed my meatloaf on the flatter side so that the cooking time wouldn't dramatically increase. In my case, an extra 5 minutes (total of 55 minutes) was perfect!

Wow! I am amazed - A dish with quinoa that my husband said about: "you can make this again!" He didn't even notice there was quinoa until my son told him after!  The flavour was incredible. I made it with ground chicken (forgot that it was not turkey I had on hand), and used Wyko's recipe for the sauce, which my husband said "made it", so use this instead of the one with the recipe: 1/4 c brown sugar, 1/4 c ketchup, 1 tbsp regular mustard, and a few drops of Worcestershire sauce.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was tasty and different.  I followed the recipe exactly except I refrigerated the meat mixture for about an hour before shaping and baking.  With ground turkey (93/7 blend) I find this helps the meat hold together.  Make sure you like the hot sauce you use because it is very strong in this recipe.  Next time I plan to use a different brand for a different flavor profile and plan to put the topping on before refrigeration so it has time to sink farther down into the meat.  Mine was done in 35 minutes - the size and shape of the "loaf" will impact cooking time, so check early if you don't have an instant read thermometer that you leave in for the duration of cooking.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made the meatloaf exactly by the recipe except that I doubled it and cooked it as meat muffins instead of meatloaf (cooked them in 12 muffin tins for 20 minutes).  Since I planned on freezing them & I wanted a healthier meal,  I didn't put the sauce on top.  On the day I served them, I took out what I wanted and reheated.  for a sauce, I simmered a can of low sodium diced tomatoes with a little Spenda, a few shakes of hot sauce and a couple shakes of Worchestershire.  For color, I added dried parsley & chives.  I pureed the tomatoes with an immersion blender and cooked to about 1/3 the original volume.  Mashed turnips and broccoli were the perfect compliment for a healthy meal.  The turnips really complimented the meat & tomato sauce.

text:
Good, but a little salty. It may make a difference on how much sodium the turkey you are using has. I used the amount of salt indicated in the recipe but with 2 lbs. of turkey. The turkey I used had 140 mgs (6%) of sodium. If I made it again I would use 3/4 to 1 t. salt.

text:
This is fabulous! I really like the taste and texture, and it's very moist. I also like that this is a healthier recipe. I buy the Jennie-O 85% lean large package of ground turkey (48 oz) then double the rest of the ingredients. Once I have it all mixed up, I divide it in half. That allows one meatloaf for dinner that night, and I put the rest (raw) in a freezer bag for later. That way, all I do is thaw it overnight next time I want it, and throw it in the oven for dinner. 2 meals in one! The whole family loves it, and this is one of those recipes I tell everyone about!

Impromptu meal with my girlfriend.  Thoroughly impressed us both with this meatloaf.  The quinoa is succulent and adds that little al dente pop to every bite.  Don't over cook the turkey, but that always goes for turkey anything!  
I used 2 medium sized eggs.  I used a loaf shaped cooking pan b/c it was so moist it wouldn't stand up on its own.  I used ketchup and bbq sauce instead of tomato paste and hot sauce.  Though I did throw a little hot sauce in for minor kick.  
Best turkey meatloaf I've ever had.  And I can't freakin' believe I made it! lol

text:
YUM! Thanks for the idea! This came out amazing. I made a few changes:
-- I cooked the quinoa in organic, low sodium chicken broth with a tiny sliver of butter.
-- I left out the tomato paste (only because I was out) and substituted the hot sauce with bbq sauce (kid friendly). 
-- I sauteed the onions and garlic with diced carrots and celery then added thyme in the veggies for seasoning. I also made the glaze/gravy a little differently - I melted butter, added about 2 table spoons of tomato sauce, dark beer, regular raw sugar, worchestershire sauce, and garlic and added it to the top of the loaf at about 15 minutes into the bake. 

This came out so delicious! It's going down in my book of favorite recipes. Definitely a crowd pleaser!

text:
Don’t be tempted to save a few calories by using ground turkey breast.  Using ground turkey, white and dark meat, produces a flavorful and moist meatloaf.   I never use a loaf pan for meatloaf but always bake them free form on a baking sheet.  I was tempted to skip the brown sugar/ Worcestershire topping but I am glad that I went with it as it added significantly to the wonderful flavor of the meatloaf.

text:
Drew, thanks for reiterating that your recipe calls for a freestanding loaf. I have made it several times in a meatloaf pan, but after reading your recent posting, formed it in the pan and then turned the pan upside down so it popped out onto a foil lining. It was even better this way and had a nice crust all around that I didn't get in a pan. I like to add green  pepper to the onion and garlic along with 1 cup of fat free cheese to the meat mixture.

text:
I am usually a ground turkey hater, but this was pretty good--good enough that I'll make it again.  The cooking time made for a slightly overcooked product in my oven (I really need a thermometer) and I think the hot sauce needs to be scaled back (used Tabasco--was very spicy and overpowered the other flavors, even though I like heat).  

I had to use garlic powder instead of fresh garlic, ketchup instead of tomato paste, and I added a stalk of finely chopped celery.  I also added some ketchup and lemon juice to the glaze because I didn't like the flavor of just brown sugar & Worcestershire. 

Thanks for an easy, healthful recipe!

text:
I had never made meatloaf before but I have always loved it with beef. We had ground chicken (instead of turkey) and decided to try this recipe, it was fabulous! We doubled the amounts and added a "jerk hot sauce" instead of the "hot pepper sauce" and the jerk flavour burst through the meatloaf. We also had to substitute the Worcestershire sauce with an oriental anchovy sauce as we didn't have any Worcestershire sauce on hand.  Instead of tomato paste we used "Diana Sauce, original"...again, due to not having tomato paste. I also forgot to add the salt but it didn't matter, we added it later to taste and simply enjoyed every savoury mouthful! Excellent!!

text:
This meatloaf is AMAZING! It has such a great flavor. I added a few squirts of sriracha as the "hot pepper sauce" and it gave it a great kick! Next time I will probably add more (red) quinoa just because it is so nutritious and gives a great texture. I was a little surprised by how small this meatloaf was. I cooked it in a glass bread loaf dish and when I took it out of the oven, it had shrunk around the edges. It was perfect for my boyfriend and I and we even had leftovers, but if you're cooking for a larger family, you may want to double the recipe! the loaf dish was perfect because it was able to cook in it's own juiciness!

userID:
5757388
Display Name:
holly
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
7
favoritesCount:
7
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674134.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
LOVED THIS! It was super moist, doubled the recipe for a group of 5 adults and 5 kids (only one little guy). I did improvise quite a bit, here's what I did:  -Cut salt and pepper in half -Substituted BBQ sauce for hot sauce -Skipped the worcester -Added 1 C cheddar Jack cheese (could be reduced fat I'm sure, but adds moisture) -Made a mistake and included 2 tbls of brown sugar (used splenda blend) INTO the meatloaf instead of on top and it was actually really good, if you don't want it too sweet you could leave this out or cut it in half. -Cooked Quinoa in chicken broth =Tried to rinse the quinoa but didn't have a strainer thin enough so didnt' really do that.  I cooked the 2 loaves at 350 for about 1.5 hours in 2 loaf pans and they came out perfectly, not dry at all!  My husband who HATES meatloaf, actually liked this!

5

We found these moist and tasty and the quinoa added a great something extra. Will definitely be making this again.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This meatloaf was really great! My grocery store didn't have quinoa, so I used couscous, which seemed to work really well also. I'd really like to try it with the quinoa next time, but if you do use the couscous, throw some herbs into it as it cooks and/or use chicken broth, just to give it a little extra flavor. I skipped the hot pepper, used ketchup instead of tomato paste, and grated up a zucchini and some baby carrots into it as well (I had prepared 1/2c of couscous, and ended up using all of it to bind the meatloaf together with all of the veggies' extra water). I also threw in some dried basil and parsley to give a little bit of extra flavor. My 2yr old, who doesn't care for meat very much, LOVED it- he was dipping his pieces in ketchup and had most of his serving finished before my husband and I sat down! Served it with mashed sweet potatoes and garlic green beans- very tasty and pretty easy. Will definitely get worked into my meal rotation!

I really love this recipe and so does my husband! The only things I changed are additions: I add a cup of shredded carrots to the mix, and it really kicks up the flavor and healthy aspects. As well as cooking the quinoa in low sodium beef broth; by doing this the meatloaf ends up having a heartier taste. But by far the best part of the recipe is the sauce on top! If you let it run over the sides of the  loaf, the flavor will soak into the entire thing....so yummy!!!

I made this for my family tonight and we loved it. The brown sugar paste, as written here, didn’t turn out as a paste. I added another tablespoon of brown sugar and it probably could have used a 4th for consistency, but I was afraid it would be too sweet. Next time, I won't add a teaspoon of water. But I will definitely make this again. Easy and very tasty.

text:
I followed the instructions as written.  I used Green Dragon hot sauce from Trader Joe’s instead of a traditional red hot sauce. This type of hot sauce did not cause it to be spicy at all as some reviewers said; it just added some flavor. I baked them in a regular size muffin tin (it made 6 overflowing “muffins”) at 350 for 30 minutes.  These held their shape nicely and were very moist.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this over the weekend. I bought 2 one lb. packages of ground turkey, not realizing that the recipe's package was 20 oz. I doubled all ingredients, plus the extra egg and mixed it all up - it was like soup! I know that I didn't have the right quantity of turkey, so I ran to the store and bought another pound. The math said I should have only needed to add 1/2 pound, but I ended up adding the whole pound and it was still very wet, but could keep a shape. I will attempt to make again with the correct amount of turkey, and not double it and see if it comes out less wet. That being said -- the taste is PHENOMENAL!! I also substituted the hot sauce with BBQ sauce. My husband hates eating recipes that use ground turkey instead of beef, and he says he can't stand quinoa. I didn't tell him what was in the meal - just that it was meatloaf. He ate it up!! I still haven't told him, yet, because we have quite a bit left to eat. But really, really yummy. I will be making it again.

text:
I was craving meatloaf but wanted to be health-conscious. This hit the spot! I had to open a whole can of tomato paste, so after using the one tablespoon in the meatloaf mixture, I mixed the rest of the can in with the brown sugar and Worcestershire sauce for the topping. I added a splash more Worcestershire sauce, a few shakes of garlic salt, and 2 tablespoons more of water and frosted the meatloaf with the stuff like a cake. Excellent! I can’t wait to eat the leftovers tomorrow!

text:
I was searching for what to do with a pound of ground turkey and found this recipe. My 7 year old son loved it! I did modify it slightly because I didn’t have all of the ingredients...I used 2 tbsp ketchup, 2 tbsp bbq sauce and 1 tsp sriracha sauce instead of the tomato paste, Worcester sauce and brown sugar. I made it in an 8x8 Pyrex...when baked, I drained off a little water from the top and covered it in cheddar then continued to bake until the cheese melted.

This was my first time to ever make anything with ground turkey, so I was glad to read the comment about not putting it in a pan because it would be soggy. I followed the recipe as written, except I didn't include the hot sauce. I used red quinoa, which added a nice bit of color to the finished meatloaf. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've experimented with quite a few turkey meatloaf recipes and this was probably the best one I've made. I loved the tip about using a baking sheet instead of a loaf pan to keep it from steaming and getting mushy. That and the quinoa helped give it a firm but tender texture. My husband is not a fan of quinoa but didn't even notice it was in there. The flavor was great, though slightly salty for my taste. I would probably just use one teaspoon of salt next time. I loved the hot sauce--it wasn't too spicy but added a nice little kick.  
My one issue was that, although I followed the recipe exactly (2 T brown sugar, 2 t Worcestershire, 1 t water)the sauce was not a paste. It was very thin and ran down the sides of the loaf, pooling around the edges.  But it tasted good regardless.

It was very good, I only had 1lbs of ground turkey so I added a leftover of ~5oz  tofu, 2 eggs instead of 1,  green onions, half the salt indicated, and a dash of hot pepper sauce. I cooked it on a flat baking sheet.

Thanks, Drew!!  Love this recipe - and your explanation of how beef and poultry cook differently was really helpful.  For what it's worth, I keep a container of already-cooked quinoa in the freezer for occasions like this one so I can skip the step of cooking and cooling it and just add what I need to a recipe.  A few seconds (or so) in the microwave on low power and the frozen quinoa separates easily when poked with a butter knife.  Thanks again.  (c:

text:
I have made this recipe many times and my whole family, including my picky eater, loves it.  Wonderful flavor and so much healthier than beef meat loaf.  I usually double the paste that goes on top and I have never added the hot pepper sauce because I don't have any and my little ones don't like it.  The last time I made it I didn't have any quinoa on hand so I substituted a 1/4 cup oats and ketchup for the tomato paste. I also was in a hurry and didn't sauté the onion, just chopped it up and threw it in and it still turned out great.  I do prefer the original recipe though, especially the nutrients and flavor the quinoa adds.

I really liked it and frankly am surprised by the less positive reviews. It's healthy, easy to make and my daughter really liked it. I made it exactly per the recipe, and (against my nature) formed it into a loaf and putting it on top of a foil-lined sheet instead of a loaf pan and found it tasty and not at all dried out as others have said. (Now, if I had used a normal sized loaf pan dryness may have been a problem because it wouldn't have filled one fully) The only complaint that I have with the recipe is I think less brown sugar would be a good thing. I don't really think meatloaf needs 2 tablespoons but that's just me trying to be healthy.

None
text:
I can't believe I made a beefless meatloaf that I like!  This was really good.  I read the reviews and made a ton of changes.  First of all I used 1 lb of chopped chicken breast meat and boiled my quinoa in chicken broth instead of water. I added about 1/4 c italian seasoned panko bread crumbs. I used a couple dashes of hot sauce, not a whole tbsp and it didn't even need that.  The pepper gives this enough of a kick (for my taste anyway).  I also used plain tomato sauce instead of tomato paste.  Last I added about 1 tbsp of the tomato sauce to the worcestershire/brown sugar topping and omitted the water.  I formed the mix into 2 loaves since everyone in my house loves the ends and baked for 35 minutes.  It was perfect.

This is hands down my favorite meatloaf recipe. I did take a few suggestions from others. I added an additional egg and 1 cup of sharp cheddar cheese. text:
Really delicious and easy to make. Thumbs up from the whole family including small children. I did not use the hot sauce but added a healthy shake of Hot Mexican Chili Powder. I also added a cup of shredded cheddar, which definitely gave it a tasty texture, and the extra egg. Next time I will try to add some more chopped, sautéed veggies to see how that holds up.  Definitely line your pan with foil, as the loaf runs and oozes quite a bit, and the cheese runs out. I rolled up the sides of the foils to make a lip, which I also recommend.

text:
I made the recipe as stated. The texture was great with the quinoa, and baking it on sheet allowed the fat to run off. It had a unique flavor, but really broke down into a basic pepper, sweet and spicy flavor. Black pepper was the prominent feature, along with sweet/salt from the Worcestershire and brown sugar. Had to think to taste the hot pepper sauce and onions. To cook the quinoa for texture wasn't worth the time. We won't make this again.

Display Name:
Yum!
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/198613.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've always found meatloaf to be just okay no matter how good the reviews were, so I was actually surprised with how tasty this recipe turned out! I was skeptical about the quinoa, but you don't even notice it. Minus one star though because I did tweak it a bit per other reviews, as well as swapped a few other ingredients to match what I had on hand. I used ketchup instead of tomato paste, BBQ sauce instead of hot sauce ("hot sauce" was a little vague since there's so many different kinds out there with unique levels of heat and flavor profiles, so I went with a surefire thing) and two eggs instead of one. The flavor and texture were perfect. I also found the glaze to be just a bit too sweet and might just replace it straight up with BBQ sauce the next time around (and there will be a next time!). I also like how easy this recipe is to halve, which is good for small households like mine. I'd say that half a loaf could feed three people reasonably. This is definitely my go-to meatloaf recipe from now on!

text:
I doubled the recipe and it came out delicious.  I added a little extra hot sauce to the brown sugar glaze sprinkled over the top.  I baked it in a 9" square casserole dish, and found that it needed extra time due to the doubled size.  Total baking time was around 1.25 hours.

Be sure to really combine the turkey and quinoa well.  Failure to do so will leave unconsolidated quinoa at the bottom of the dish.

text:
I thought this meatloaf was delicious - I made it as directed, but found it could have used another egg to hold it together.  It was crumbly even after sitting for a good 10 minutes, although I found when I was putting the leftovers away, it had firmed up.  The taste of the glaze was delicious and I liked the texture that the quinoa gave it.  Followed Drew's directions and cooked it on a foil covered cookie sheet instead of a pan and it came out just right.  Thanks!!

country:
None
text:
First thing I heard from the kids when I told them I was making meatloaf was "ew gross!" Ummmm.... They flipping LOVED it!!! All my girls cleared their plates. I adjusted the recipe as follows: left out the onions and garlic because I didn't have them on hand. I used 1/2 cup of quinoa rather than 1/4 cup. I believe it made the loaf firmer. I added garlic salt and some beef seasoning rub that I had on hand and used franks red hot in place of the chile sauce. I added about 2tablespoons of tomato paste to the glaze and cooked to melt the brown sugar. It tasted like homemade BBQ sauce. All in all this was a hit at my house. The loaf was nice and light and felt pretty healthy. I WILL DEFINITELY MAKE THIS ONE AGAIN!

text:
I'm eating leftovers and I have to say this meatloaf is much better the day after than the day off. The flavor is good... it's the texture we didn't care for too much. Sort of on the mushy side. Today the texture is more on the fluffy side and it tastes really good. Unfortunately since my BF refused to take leftovers for lunch (he ALWAYS does) I will likely not make this again. Also, the only changes I made was to add an extra egg and I cut down on the brown sugar to 1 tablespoon and added 1 tablespoon of grey poupon.

Delicious!! I made it exactly the way the recipe called for the first time and it turned out great.  Tonight I made it with ground chicken instead.  I also used two tablespoons of spaghetti sauce instead of tomato paste and a healthy dollop of franks red hot instead of hot pepper sauce. My picky hubby ate it (with a little ketchup) and even my 2 year old daughter gobbled it up.  I recommend this for everyone!  And to Drew.. Love it.  I did make this in a loaf dish and cooked it at 375 for 40 minutes.. it cut beautifully

text:
My husband raved about this. I mean, he went on & on and he NEVER does that about anything. I did customize a bit though: 1/2 turkey & 1/2 beef, added a 1/2C pureed zucchini (to hide a veggie from hubby & toddler), added more quinoa, omitted the hot pepper sauce because of my toddler, used garlic powder since I didn't have any cloves on hand, used ketchup instead of tomato paste because I didn't have any on hand. Then, I changed the topping to 1T dijon, 1T ketchup, 1T brown sugar and 2 splashes of Worcestershire. And I cooked it for 50mins in one of those As Seen On TV meatloaf pans and it worked great! My toddler even scarfed it down and she is picky! Yay! Will definitely make this again soon! :)

This was absolutely delicious.  I have to admit, I was fairly skeptical but after reading the reviews, I thought I would give it a shot.  I did use a higher fat content of turkey instead of the extremely lean ground white turkey.  I think that the addition of barbecue sauce next time would make it even better; this time I just mixed some in with the sauce for the topping and served some on the side as well.  I don't know if using a higher fat content defeats the purpose of cooking with turkey at all, but it was very good and I will be making it again.  In the future, I may try using ground turkey breast with either shredded apple or zucchini to add some moisture.  My boyfriend cleaned up all the leftovers which was so disappointing to me...I was looking forward to cold meatloaf sandwiches with spicy mustard!  Next time I'm hiding the leftovers.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/443298.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was delicious!  I loved the ideas of making it in muffin pans; I will also be trying meatballs with this recipes, too.  I did take a previous reviewer's suggestion to double the quinoa to make it stretch farther and, as with her experience, it worked out great (I added an add'l egg to help it bind).  Although, if you do this, be prepared that if you free-form it in a pan (with sides to catch run-off), it will take about twice the amount of time but it's worth it for leftovers and sandwiches.  I could not find ground turkey in my local stores so I substituted ground chicken (the butcher confirmed that it does have a mixture of white and dark meat) and it worked wonderfully!  My kids said it reminded them of chicken nuggets.  I added no salt but somehow this recipe still tasted too salty for our palates.  I will definitely be substituting low-sodium Worcestershire sauce next time.  Also, we skipped the hot pepper sauce, doubled the garlic, and added BBQ sauce to the tomato paste mixture for the glaze topping.  Thumbs-up!  Highly recommend.  Thanks, Drew :o)

text:
Great meatloaf and healthy too.  It is very moist and the quinoa gives it a nice texture.  I have made it twice and both times my husband and I loved it.
I did reduce the 1 T of hot pepper sauce to about 1/2 teaspoon of Chili Garlic Sauce and a few dashes of Tabasco. You can find the chili sauce in the Asian section of the store. Also, used just 1 T of brown sugar/splenda blend since we do a low sugar diet. The topping was still sweet and very tasty!
Excellent recipe!!

text:
Incredibly good.  I had meatloaf for the first time a few days ago at a restaurant in town.  It was good in the middle, but had a large border of tough meat that wasn't fun to eat.  Not a problem, I just brought it home for my furry little girls.  I was concerned that this would also be a problem here...but what I got was very juicy meatloaf with no hard borders.  The texture was a bit different...it fell apart a little easier.  But this dish exceeded all my expectations, and I did not pay $10 for it.  This was the centerpiece in my thanksgiving dinner (only two of us here, no point in a proper bird), which was a success.  Thank you.

text:
Very reluctant to try this recipe but it was so fabulous!  Remember to rinse your Quinoa before putting it in the saucepan.  I have been experimenting with Quinoa for almost a year now and found that this is a very important step to ensure it cooks and tastes good.  For this first recipe attempt I used 48 ounces of ground turkey and used three eggs while only doubling (but with rounded spoonfuls) the other ingredients - except for the hot sauce.  Thanks for all the tips and this amazingly delicious recipe!

I'm always looking for healthy recipes that the whole family can enjoy ... and when I say family ... there are 7 of us (our kids range from 5-14yrs old).

This is a recipe that I have been wanting to try for awhile and finally gave it a go today and am soooo glad that we did. Very few leftovers (probably enough for one large serving for myself).

Will definitely be making this again.  Based upon some other reviews, I did add an extra egg.  I also left out the hot sauce as I didn't want it to be too spicy for the kids.

text:
Delicious. Will now be one of my staple recipes. I am not a big hot sauce fan, so I substituted some buffalo wing sauce. I also used ketchup instead of tomato paste (never know what to do with the rest of the can in these situations). Since I only had 16 oz of turkey, I added bread crumbs to make up some of the difference. I free-formed it on aluminum foil as instructed, and it turned out perfect -- moist, held together, delicious. It really tastes just like beef meatloaf. Thank you for this winning recipe!

Thanks for the great recipe!

text:
I was not a big fan of this meatloaf served as-is.  I used ground turkey breast because it's what I had on hand, and I added some olive oil to account for the lost fat, but I must not have added enough because the meatloaf was quite dry.  I also did not care for the taste of the hot pepper sauce in the meatloaf.  

I am giving it three stars however, because of how good the transformed leftovers were!  The next night I crumbled the leftovers into a skillet with some water and cooked it for about 10 minutes, then used the meat as filling for tacos.  It was some of the best taco meat we've ever had!!

text:
Awesome taste! Even my meat-loving husband gave this one a thumbs up. I didn't use the hot sauce due to tender palates - just increased the ketchup (instead of tomato paste) to 2 tablespoons. I also add more ketchup to the topping to be more traditional.

Can anyone tell me why you have to cook the onions and garlic ahead of time? I'd think that after nearly an hour in the oven, they would be well cooked. (When I put raw onion in beef hamburgers and fry them, they always cook just fine.) I just put them in raw (minced) and they cook just fine.

I cook the quinoa in beef broth instead of water - adds some beef flavor.

Thanks, Drew! This has become one of my "regulars" now - healthy and tasty! :)

text:
This is a great recipe, easily adapted for the food plan I'm on.  Actually, the only real changes I made were to cut the salt in half and substitute no-sodium catsup for the tomato paste.  The only thing I would do differently next time would be to cut the Tabasco down to 2 tsp.  This was so tasty that my husband didn't realize it was turkey until I told him, and even though he's a great salt lover, didn't even notice that any was missing.  I would highly recommend this recipe to any meatloaf lover.  This is the first time I've tried turkey meatloaf and the recipe is a definite keeper!!!!!

This was pretty good.  I've tried turkey loaf before and did not care for it.  I would only stick to beef.  But then I found this recipe and gave it another try.  Especially since I just started cooking with quinoa.  I was pleasantly surprised by how this turned out.  I added about 1/3 cup of shredded ched. chez (but won't add that again since i couldn't really taste it) and added an additional egg.  I also added bbq sauce to the sauce topping.  The quinoa helped with the texture to make it more meatloaf-y.  Instead of making it as a loaf, I made it into individual mounds and baked them for about a 1/2 hr.  My toddlers even liked these so I will definitely be making them again.

I didn't have quinoa so I substituted millet and read on a vegan cooking site that they substitute fine for each other in recipes. I followed the cooking directions for millet first.. dry-skillet toasting it to bring out flavor then boiling it with water to soften/cook it. But I have to say it made the meatloaf taste sort of like sawdust! That's not anyone's fault but mine, of course.. because the spices in the meatloaf were delicious with the turkey. I was still glad to try the recipe and maybe I'll try it again sometime as it's posted-- with quinoa. Definitely don't substitute!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Cooking for family, I followed the advice of others and did not add the hot pepper sauce. While making the loaf, I noticed that the Worcestershire had chili paste in it which was fine for the loaf but I thought was too spicy for the topping-paste; decided to toss that topping mixture and instead made a paste of equal parts ketchup and brown sugar.

Made this ahead on Thursday evening and served for dinner on Saturday. I put the meat in a bread loaf pan and sealed with saran wrap (pressed right on top of loaf and then up sides of pan so no air was in there.) Kept the top-paste separate in a pyrex dish to add right before baking. Stored in fridge.

Everyone ate it! Two picky boys 4+7, husband who usually can't stand meatloaf, my mom who doesn't eat read meat, my very health-conscious dad, and me. Served with grilled, seasoned, sliced potatoes and peas. Grown-ups all had more than one piece, and there were a few leftovers which were tasty too. Will make this again! Husband said I should triple the ketchup-brown sugar topping next time.

4 stars due to the alterations, 5 stars for the idea/inspiration!

Display Name:
Schwemmette

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fantastic!  I never follow a recipe to the letter but the only change I made to this was to add the rest of my can of tomato paste to the topping/glaze.  My husband is such a huge fan of this recipe that he requested it again for next week.  As I write this, I'm wishing we hadn't already eaten all the leftovers!

Update: I found a great technique for making this meatloaf.  I double the recipe and pat it into a cookie sheet (size dictates thickness of "slices"), spreading the glaze on top.  I bake at 350 for 15-20 minutes.  Then I can cut it into portions and freeze the leftovers.  Just wrap individual pieces in wax paper and pop them all in a freezer bag.  They reheat wonderfully in the microwave!  My hubby loves to take them for lunch and when I was on bedrest at the end of my pregnancy and then recovering from the c-section, having a freezer full of protein-packed meatloaf was a life saver!

Also, in recent batches, I've used garam masala for the seasoning and the rhubarb steak sauce from allrecipes.com in the glaze.  Incredible!

text:
Had no quinoa, so used burgol instead.  Had no tomato paste, so used tomato sauce instead.  Had no brown sugar; so used white instead. Had no hot pepper sauce so used Hot Chili sauce instead.  And it came out very tasty.  It didn't keep a shape so I poured it into an English cake pan lined with baking paper.  It came out perfect and very very good.  I would give it 5 stars, but after all...it's only meatloaf!

text:
After reading other reviews, I made the following adjustments. I omitted the worcestershire sauce and used LS Soysauce (only 1 Tbsp).  I reduced the hot pepper sauce to 1/2tsp, omitted the salt, reduced black pepper to 1/2tsp, used egg substitute in place of egg, used cooking spray instead of oil, omitted the brown sugar.  The additions I made were to add panko bread crumbs, dried oregano, dried basil and homemade tomato sauce on the top.  I used a loaf pan which I'd highly recommend to keep its shape.  I love the flavor of the a quinoa.  This was excellent.  My husband loved it.  I will make this again.

Really good!  Added 1 extra egg and shook in some panko to help as it was a little loose.  Shook in some cheddar cheese but probably doesn't need it, couldn't notice it.  I subbed sweet chili sauce for the hot sauce, and subbed ketchup for the tomato paste (rather than open a can for this little amt.).  
For the topping I did 1/4 C. br. sugar, 1/4 C. ketchup, 1 T. mustard and added some worcestershire.) 
I put it on a PAM sprayed, foil lined sheet (used one that had sides).  Formed it into a rectangle.

Turned out great!   Reduced hot sauce to 1 tsp.   Used veggie bullion in the quinoa cooking process.  Added yellow peppers.  Made (2) 1-lb loaves from all dark meat that I cooked on a raised rack with perforated parchment paper.  To do this, I put parchment paper on a cooking rack and used a fork to poke drain holes.  Placed rack on a pan and put loaves on top of the paper.  Great texture and flavor!

text:
I was reluctant to make Turkey meatloaf due to the stories that I'd heard.  Girlfriend can't eat beef and loves quinoa, so this recipe seemed appropriate. 
Thanks, Andrew Benoit for putting together an amazing and healthy Turkey meatloaf. 
I used 99% fat free ground Turkey and added a second egg to help bind the ingredients. 

I used a Rachel Ray meatloaf pan which has allows juices to drip through, which deals with any exces moisture. 

I'll make this again and add salsa to the mix and on top of the loaf.

Found this recipe when I was fishing for something interesting to do with ground turkey, and am I glad I did! The nuttiness of the quinoa and the bite of the hot sauce brought the turkey to life.

I ended up using 30 ounces of ground meat, half of which, I think, was ground chicken. I also used two eggs and 1.5x the quantity of just about everything else. The quinoa makes a surprinsingly good filler and the loaf did indeed hold together well. You bet I'll make this again!

text:
This was ridiculously good!  I've been using All Recipes for years but have rarely commented.  I felt I had to this time.  I totally did not miss the taste of traditional meatloaf.  The texture was perfect.  I was short on time so, I didn't measure anything but the seasoning.  I reduced sodium to 1 tsp since there was worchestire in the recipe and I try to watch sodium.  I used a little extra garlic, a medium onion and one extra egg since I didn't have ground turkey thigh and breast can be dry.  Also, I cooked in two loaves to expedite cook time.  Finally, since I'm not a big fan of tomato based sauce on meatloaf, I didn't add a sauce.

text:
This was really good. I will try and rate the recipe as written although I omitted a few items because we are limiting our salt and sugar intake. I used 99 % lean ground white meat turkey.  It was kind of genius to use the quinoa as the binding agent. I also used two eggs.  Although I do not care to wash extra pans, cooking the onion and garlic before adding to the loaf is a good idea. Nothing worse than undercooked onions. The loaf texture was ok; it held together but was not too dense. Cooking time was spot on. I omitted the topping but put beefsteak tomatoes on top instead.   This was a pretty good recipe.

I have made this many times as it is a definite favorite in our home.   As far as ingredients go, we do not deviate from the recipe one bit.  We do, however, bake it in a two-piece loaf pan we bought at Meijer that actually drops all of the grease under the pan and collects it away from the loaf.  It is PERFECT for this recipe. text:
I love this recipe! It always turns out so moist and people are surprised it's turkey. I have changed the recipe based on the items I have on hand. I use a quinoa and brown rice mixture along with my own homemade ketchup. Since turkey cooks off a lot of moisture, I find I have to drain the liquid immediately after cooking so it doesn't make the bottom of the loaf soggy. I use a low rim flat  pan which seems to work well for this dish.

Display Name:
Joseph Brown
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674133.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I use quinoa for meatballs as well, so this recipe caught my attention. Meatloaf is one of those fun meals in that it's very forgiving to alteration. I followed pretty close, but did use a few less ounces of turkey and added bell peppers and fresh basil. 

I also opted to bake in a loaf pan and didn't have issues with sogginess. Once baked, I removed from the pan and collected the drippings to drizzle over the sliced meatloaf for added effect.

Just as the contributor intended, the quinoa is a great replacement for the traditional breadcrumbs and adds great texture and flavor retention to  the dish. It's a double benefit for added protein, fewer simple carbs, and puts meatloaf back on the menu for my gluten intolerant wife.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1427990.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made a few changes and it was the best meat loaf I've had.  I made the quinoa in chicken broth, used a sweet BBQ sauce instead of the hot sauce, and covered the top in ketchup.  The sauce that is supposed to go on top I mixed all of those ingredients just into the main bowl with everything else and didn't use as a topping.  Also I used two eggs because they were farm fresh eggs so on the smaller side.  I cooked it on parchment paper on a pan with 1/2" sides.  Paired it with steamed broccoli.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2787858.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Pretty good! For extra nutrition, I added a shredded carrot, some shredded spinach as well finely diced red peppers sautéed along with the onion.  After mixing in the quinoa, egg, and spices (I added both garlic & onion powders, a bit of Lawrey's seasoned salt and parsley), I decided to throw in 1/8 c of panko and a small handful of parmesan cheese. I baked it in a 9" pie plate for 50 minutes, but would reduce that to 40-45 min next time, as it came out just a tiny bit drier than expected (although it could've been the addition of the panko as well).  I served it with some steamed sweet corn and it went over very well with both the husband and picky 9 year-old daughter. Overall, 4 stars and this recipe will be made again.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3616822.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I usually don't like turkey, but seeing all the good review and tempted by the quinoa which I just bought a big bag at Costco and need t find way to use it, I decided to give it a try. It is very delicious and nutritious! I had only one pound of turkey (following the author's recommendation of using white and dark meat) used 2 eggs, instead of 1, a large onion, which makes it sweeter,  and only a little bit of sriracha because that's what I have and we don't like spicy. Finally, I use baby ray BBQ sauce to replace the hot sauce. I didn't top it with anything because I don't like sugar. I baked it in a pie dish for exactly 50 minutes. When it first came out of the oven, there is some gooey juice on top but was absorbed back into the meat loaf.  It's the tastiest turkey meatloaf I ever tasted, and it's much lighter than beef.

text:
THE BEST recipe for turkey meatloaf I have ever found (and I have been looking for 10+ years)!  The only omission I made was the hot sauce because I don't like it.   The quinoa was not discernible as a flavor or texture but adds so much more nutrition than bread crumbs.  I baked this in a meatloaf pan with a perforated insert to let the drippings fall through.   The loaf was moist and tender but held together and sliced really well.   Thanks for a great recipe-this is the only turkey meatloaf I will ever make!

My family loved this recipe!  I added an extra egg on the advice of reviewers, and made a couple of changes for our tastes, and according to what I had on hand.  I used a couple tablespoons chopped sun-dried tomatoes and some left-over  canned fire-roasted tomatoes (about 1/2 cup). A family member is avoiding wheat, and the quinoa is a wonderful substitute for bread crumbs...light and tasty.

text:
IMPORTANT DETAIL: This does not get cooked in a loaf pan! Read the author's post-script about how turkey has a lot of liquid and it ends up all "fall-aparty" if you don't cook it on a baking sheet. If I had paid attention to that detail, I would have gone a step further and elevated it off the bottom of the baking pan. 
THAT BEING SAID: This may have been the first meatloaf I've made without a seasoning packet and it was wonderful despite the fall-aparty-ness. The flavor was perfect.

text:
This was pretty good and very easy.  I omitted tomato paste because I was out and I used a large red onion and 16 oz. of ground turkey (because it came in 1 pound packages).  Even with these alterations, the end result was delicious.  Next time I will add another egg to help the loaf stay together better and use a small onion, as written.  I shaped it like one big mounded loaf on a baking sheet.  It omits a fair amount of liquid so I recommend cooking it on something with raised sides.

region:

country:
None
text:
Fantastic! I read some reviews and added some stuff and it was delicious. Juicy, flavorful and perfectly cooked. Served with mashed potatoes and peas. I added: some shredded cheddar, few shakes of dried rosemary, an extra egg, a tiny bit of breadcrumbs only cause I didnt have enough quinoa, ketchup replaced tomato paste only cause I didnt have it and did 1/2 the hot sauce and replaced the other half with bbq sauce per other suggestions. For the top I mixed 1/4c ketchup, 1/4c brown sugar, 1tbsp dijon and a bit of Worcestershire sauce.  I put mine in greased cupcake pans for 40mins at 350, then took them off and placed on a baking sheet for another 8mins. I wanted freezable extras. Would make again any day.

text:
I have to give this 5 stars.  I have started changing my diet to clean eating, and have been doing it for about 4 months now.  I look up new recipes all the time to keep from getting bored.  My husband refuses to  eat anything that is "healthy" so I usually make a veggie for me, prepare a meat dish he will eat and then make my own side dish, like brown rice or whole grain pasta, while he sticks to packaged rice dishes or regular pasta.  I wanted to try this recipe, so i told him it was a turkey meatloaf with quinoa instead of bread crumbs, and that i could make it personal size for just me.  He said "fine....I'll try it!!"  I was shocked he would even try, since I bought low sodium ham at the deli and he wouldn't even try a taste.  When dinner was ready, he was prepared to drown the meatloaf in gravy or ketchup if it was gross.  Well, it passed with flying colors.  he went back for a second helping, and took some for leftovers the next day.  he also said he wouldn't mind if i made it again.  One small step toward getting him to join me in eating healthier!! Thank you!!!  I had to leave out the hot sauce, cuz hubby doesn't do well with spicy, but someday i will make a small one for me with that, as i Love spicy!!!

Used two eggs, and didn't have onion, so I used two shallots instead.  Tiny sprinkle of cayenne since I didn't have any kind of hot sauce. Skipped the topping altogether.  Put it in a pile (it was too gloppy to form into any other shape) in the middle of a 9x13 sprayed with Pam, and halfway thru cooking I took it out, poured off liquid, and used two small cutting boards to shape it into a loaf-like shape. Yum - and super easy cleanup!

text:
My family loves this recipe as is.  However, there are opportunities for variation - we especially like adding grated carrots and dried cranberries (almost like a thanksgiving effect) to the recipe, and omitting the brown sugar topping (too sweet).  I also interchange ketchup w tomato paste, and on occasion will also use quick cook oats to "thicken" or dry up the mix.  I always cook them as little meatballs - kid friendly and freezer friendly when the kiddos need a fast meal ready made in the morning!

text:
I really like how it is so moist.  I subbed Sirracha since I was out of "hot sauce."  Added about half of what it called for and although I can tolerate it, my kids probably will find it too hot.  I would decrease it even more so the next time. I also was out of Worcestershire  sauce, so I made a paleo-friendly Worcestershire  sauce, which was quite simple.  It all came out fine.  I thought the topping was a bit on the sweet side but I'm accustomed to low sugar recipes, so it's probably just me.  I would make it again, especially if my kids like it.  I prefer this GF, lower carb alternative to reg. meatloaf recipes.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After having made this over a dozen times, I have to say this is an absolute favorite of mine. I have made slight adjustments to the recipe each time and think I finally found the adjustments that make it my all time favorite.

Instead of only 1/4 cup of quinoa, I use 1 cup uncooked quinoa (likely about 2 cups cooked) in the final recipe. I also use an entire chopped white onion.

I added 4 tbsp of tomato paste for a redder color and more flavor as well as about 2 tbsp pepper. With additional quinoa and onion, I feel the extra tomato paste and pepper help keep the flavor. 

I also left the glaze off my most recent attempt at the recipe and actually much preferred it and felt it was healthier without the brown sugar.

This recipe, whether made as listed or with your own variations, will not disappoint!

Lastly - I cook this in muffin pans for easy serving sizes and a slightly reduced cooking time.

text:
This meatloaf is incredible!  I've tried many recipes from AllRecipes over the years and this is by far one of our favorites that we continue to make again and again.  I use 93/7 turkey, red quinoa and Tabasco for my hot sauce.  I add just a few shakes of salt and pepper.   Following the advice of another reviewer, I changed the topping to 1/4 c ketchup, 1/4 c brown sugar, 1 T ground mustard and a few splashes of Worcestershire sauce.  The loaf I just made read 187 degrees on the meat thermometer after 45 minutes at 350 degrees in the oven.  As always, it came out moist and tasty! My husband made his into a sandwich on sourdough.  I ate it with green beans and salad.  This dish is quick to put together and makes for an easy clean up and tasty leftovers.  Try it!  You'll love it!

text:
I really enjoyed this recipe. My only regret is telling my quinoa hating guy that this wasn't a "real" meatloaf. He hears quinoa and it's all over. This recipe was moist and tasty and I'd make it again. I'd listened to other reviews and made my standard topping of ketchup/brown sugar, but I think that was a mistake. Next time I'll use the recipe topping. I also won't use Tabasco as the "hot sauce". I used half the amount and it still had a bite.  Overall satisfied and think this is a great alternative to ground beef and bread crumbs.

I made mainly as suggested, though I did add two eggs as many reviewers recommended.  For the topping, instead of using what the recipe asked for, I mixed about a tablespoon and a half of Famous Dave's Rich and Sassy BBQ Sauce and a tablespoon and a half of spicy brown mustard and spread over the meatloaf before going in the oven with a basting brush and it was delicious, my husband loved it and immediately asked for it to go in the rotation.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is EXCELLENT - possibly our new favorite meal!! It's moist, it's got a little kick, and the sweetness from the topping balances it out perfectly. SO good! I combed through all the reviews to find the best alterations and this is what I changed:
A. Cooking
- I doubled this recipe because it is DELICIOUS!
- I cooked half of my batch in muffin tins (350F, 32 mins), the other half as two separate loafs
B. Loaf Ingredients
- 1 tbs ketchup instead of 1 tbs tomato paste
- 1/2 tbs hot pepper sauce instead of 1 whole tbs (it still had enough kick!)
- 1.5 egg instead of 1
- 1/2 tsp rosemary (added)
- 1/2 a zucchini, diced (added)
- 1/2 cup shredded sharp cheddar (added)
C. Topping Ingredients (another reviewer's recipe)
1/4 cup brown sugar
1/4 cup ketchup
1 tbs mustard
1/2 tsp Worcestershire

Display Name:
Tim and Amy Byers
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7519911.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This turkey recipe is as close as it gets to beef folks! I stopped eating beef 10 years ago and have been able to find a tasty meat or protein substitute for just about all of my favorite beef recipes, with the exception of the classic American meatloaf.  My previous attempts at turkey meatloaf always seemed a little bland and watery, at least until now.  The quinoa cleverly disguises the ground turkey, both in appearance and taste.  My husband who is all about meat and potatoes even admitted this could be mistaken as beef.  I eliminated the hot sauce and it was still very flavorful.  Be sure to wait the full 10 minutes before slicing and it will hold together nicely.   I revised the glaze since we are attempting  to reduce sugar intake.  Substituted the brown sugar with 2 tablespoons of organic ketchup and mixed with the 2 teaspoons Worcestershire sauce. Sliced the entire loaf to store and now look forward to cold meatloaf sandwiches!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Besides eating quinoa as a replacement of my starch (rice), this was the FIRST recipe I tried with quinoa & first time making meatloaf. I am impressed!!

Flavor: very flavorful and delicious
Moisture: very moist
Difficulty: beginner

I followed the recipe as close as possible with some changes based on the reviews.
Changes I've made:
- 1 more egg
- Half the salt (you can always add but not take out!)
- Half the brown sugar
- Ketchup (didn't have tomato paste)
- BBQ sauce (didn't want spice)

Recipe was easy to follow. Took a little while from start to finish, just because it had to bake. It IS a very soft mixture (because it's so moist!) so it was interesting to mold into a loaf shape. Because it's so moist, it won't be nice & tall like a traditional meatloaf but honestly, who cares? It's sooooo good! :)

WILL DEFINITELY MAKE AGAIN!! I'm already drooling...

I added julianned zucchini and squash, about 1/3 of a cup total, to increase the healthy factor.  I also used significantly more garlic, 4 cloves.  The "paste" did not turn into a paste even when I added extra brown sugar, but I poured it over the loaf and it turned out fine.  Just noting that it's not a paste, don't expect it to be.  Overall, it was a good dish and I will be making it again.  Thanks for the recipe!

text:
Amazing!..this is a great start but here is how I tweaked it to take this recipe over the top. 1st, cooked quinoa in chicken stock, as I always do and others have noted, 2nd, used bbq sauce instead of hot sauce as it meshes better with the Worcestershire sauce, to get that heat back add a dash of cayenne, then add fresh sage and rosemary from the yard and finally about a 1/4 cup of fresh grated parm!

text:
I LOVE this recipe. Ground turkey always seems so blah, so after fixing this, it's been a permanent addition to the dinner rotation. I add chopped zucchini to mine, and after reading other reviews, I also add another egg. Instead of breadcrumbs, I've added smushed up croutons- SO GOOD! I also suggest cooking your quinoa in chicken broth, makes a big flavor difference. I use Franks Red Hot, and I'm a mild gal, wasn't too spicy for me, even my 16 month old goes to town on this. Thanks so much for the wonderful recipe!

text:
A bit spicy for my seven year old, but we liked it very much overall.  Changes made: cut salt to 1/2 t, added 1/2 t thyme, 1/4 c diced red pepper, substitute ketchup for tomato paste (easier).  Next time, I might add extra egg to see if it will hold together better. We liked glaze, but half would have been enough, the rest just ran off and burnt in the oven.

text:
I made this almost exactly to the recipe, making sure I used a combination of white and dark turkey meat.  For the hot sauce I used Sriracha sauce.  I served it with roasted vegetables.  It actually took about an hour to cook, but was so worth the wait.  I am by no means an accomplished cook, but this was delicious!!  Whoever said in the reviews that it needed more flavor, I can't understand.  Several people said they didn't use the topping that the recipe called for, and I believe that was a mistake, because it tied everything together so well and brought out a delicious taste.  I will definitely make this again!!

userID:
2170214
Display Name:
Greg Ulrich
isPro:
False
followersCount:
7
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
45
favoritesCount:
243
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3343267.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe as is, and it also adapts easily to use whatever else is in the fridge. I doubled the recipe size by adding a pound of  ground chicken to the ground turkey. In the fry pan, along with the grilled onions, I added half of a red bell pepper, finely diced, half of a zucchini, again, finely diced, and a carrot, finely shredded. In addition to the cooked quinoa, I added half a cup of oats, and a few tablespoons of milk(put this into a large bowl first, allow milk and oats to soak while frying vegetables) I didn't have tomato paste, so I used a tablespoon of ketchup instead. In addition to the black pepper, I added a heavy dash of cumin, turmeric, and coriander. Mixed it all up using 3 eggs, shaped it into a loaf in a 9x13 glass baking dish, then topped it off with a lattice of woven thin sliced bacon, tucking the ends under the loaf(used about 10 strips, 5 in each direction). In the last ten minutes of baking, I drizzled 2 tablespoons of raspberry chipotle marinade, instead of the brown sugar-Worcestershire mix to glaze. It was awesome!

text:
This meatloaf didn't really end up being a meatloaf. I ended up having to just dump it out the loaf pan and cooking it in a skillet. It tastes really good, I'm just disappointed in how soft and loose it was. And due to the tomato paste, it had a pinkish/red tint to it and a "wet" look that made me uncomfortable because it didn't look "done". I'm trying the whole low carb bit so I was really excited to find a meatloaf that didn't require breadcrumbs. But I was weary of it because I wasn't sure how it was going to bind together. Something told me to use a small amount of breadcrumbs.  And I was right, I should have. I guess it's a matter of preference too. I like my meatloaf to be dense, maybe others don't. Also, I wasn't aware that it was supposed to be cooked flat. I just assumed otherwise since its meatloaf. But it is a flavorful meatloaf. Hopefully, if you're making this then you read the reviews first

city:

country:

text:
I made this with some hesitancy, but we absolutely loved the final result. I had to make some changes based on what we had on hand. I didn't have garlic or onions, so it was essentially turkey, quinoa, cheese (1/2C (60g) - I wanted some, not a lot) and spices. In addition to the recipe, I added quite a bit of onion and garlic powder, a touch of cumin, used one tablespoon of barbecue sauce in place of the hot pepper sauce, and since I didn't have tomato paste, I used one tablespoon of pasta sauce. I also rubbed a thin layer of barbecue sauce on the outside instead of the rub. I was worried the barbecue sauce (Montgomery Inn) would overwhelm, but it didn't. I also cooked the quinoa in water with a chicken bouillon cube, and the one egg was plenty. Shaped it as suggested, plopped it into the center of a 9x13 dish, and 50 minutes later we had an extremely tasty, yet healthy, meatloaf! Thanks so much for the recipe, the quinoa really makes it!

text:
It was just so-so.  My own turkey meatloaf much better.  Use breadcrumbs instead of quinoa (about half a cup or more- add enough until you get the texture you like).  Also throw in some frozen peas/carrots along with the onions.  I also don't feel the need to pre-cook the onions- 45 minutes of cooking the entire meatloaf is plenty time to cook the onion.  I also throw in a garlic/onion/parsley dried spice called "Parsley Patch" for seasoning.  Also add some mile and skip the worscestershire / brown sugar thing.  Simply top with ketchup instead before you bake.

I made this for dinner last night, and both my husband and I were pleasantly surprised by how delicious it was.  I have tried using turkey in the past, and no matter what I did, it was always bland and boring.  We loved the flavor and the texture of this, and it will definitely be my "go-to" recipe for turkey loaf in the future.  I did use less hot sauce (1 tsp instead of 1 tbsp) than indicated as highly-spiced foods don't agree with me, and I added a tablespoon more tomato paste as I love tomato flavor.

The first time I made it, I left out the hot sauce (personal preference - I knew it would not work for my family's tastes so I just left it out) and added some basil - I have to add basil when I use any form of tomato in a dish :) - and otherwise followed the recipe as written and my family and I loved it! I tried this recipe tonight and it came out really good.  Moist and very flavourful.  It was a hit.  

I did make a few small changes tho.  I cooked the quinoa in chicken broth instead of water (and for 1/4 of a cup it's 1 1/2 cups of broth, not just 1/2 cup as it suggests in the recipe), I grated a small zucchini and mixed it into step 4, and I added about a 1/2-3/4 teaspoon of Italian Seasoning for flavour.

text:
Wow! I used boxed quinoa flavored with garlic & olive oil as this was all I had on hand. Even with the quinoa being flavored, I still followed the recipe with the exception of reducing the salt. I also doubled this recipe for my family of six, and scaled back on the hot sauce to make it kid friendly. Was this ever tasty!!! You can't even tell it's made with turkey! It's moist, flavorful, and simple to prepare! I used a loaf pan without any problems. I just drained off the excess drippings halfway through cooking and again before serving. I tasted the glaze as written and knew it would be a bit too savory for my children's taste buds, so I added some ketchup to it and it was perfect! All four kids asked for seconds and one even helped herself to a THIRD serving! The leftovers were even better the next day! Thanks for an awesome recipe!!!

text:
I slightly increased the quinoa and cooked it in a stoneware loaf pan despite the suggestion not to. Ended up leaving it in the oven closer to 1 hour and 15 min to be sure it was done. It was moist, flavorful, and I couldn't bear to drizzle it with ketchup like I do with regular meatloaf. Definitely will make it again.

UPDATE: second time making this, still added more quinoa and also a second egg. Didn't have tomato paste, subbed ketchup. Was rushed so I threw the glaze ingredients into the mix by mistake, made a slightly sweeter meatloaf but still delicious. Also glazed with BBQ sauce (yum!) And added small cubes of cheddar cheese in the mix. Cooked on sheet pan as directed, but it was raw in the middle after 50 min. Another 20-25 min,  and I'd say it was done.

Well this recipe did end up being everything I thought it would be, and I can't believe I was eating healthy! I did add the extra egg to bind it a little more and I used a only a few dashes of Cholula for my hot sauce! I chose to cook this in a loaf pan because it seemed easiest to me. Seriously can't believe how tasty this was! My husband fell in love with me all over again! THANK YOU DREW

text:
My very first attempt at meatloaf (turkey or otherwise) ever and it turned out wonderful! I was shopping at TJs so no Worcestershire sauce instead I used the Trader Joe's brand steak sauce ultimately probably making the whole dish a little sweeter. My only hiccup was that the 15-20 minute cooking time for the Quinoa was way too long. I ended up burning it and charing the pan. I ended up doubling the amount I cooked (only using half) -- my saucepan was probably just too big -- and cooking for ten minutes. I will, for sure make this again and enjoy the leftovers this week. Thanks Drew!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3259326.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Thank you for this recipe. I was looking for tips on how to make a flavorful turkey meatloaf. Quinoa is a much more flavorful and nutritious addition than regular breadcrumbs. I used this recipe and basic method as a template for an Asian-inspired teriyaki turkey meatloaf with quinoa, so I can not comment on the exact proportion of spices and ingredients this recipe yields, but the quinoa was a great, nutty, hearty addition to the meat. I used ground white meat turkey because that's what I had. I'm sure a mix of white and dark meat would have been more flavorful, but it was still quite good. The meatloaf looked like a big unappetizing blob with congealed egg liquid all around it when it came out of the oven, but after resting it for 15 minutes and slicing it on a platter, it looked quite  nice. Thank you!

text:
I followed all the directions...i shaped the mixture into a loaf and baked it on a regular baking pan.. But about 15 min into baking, the meatloaf was falling apart and there was a lot of liquid and oil coming out of it.. It was a complete mess.  The mixture was wayyyy too mushy to hold shape.   I had to transfer the meat into a loaf pan.  I'll see how that goes.   Anybody else have the same problem? The only change i had to make was i used 1lb of ground turkey instead of 20 oz (thats how they came in a pkg and i reduced all the other ingredients a little bit) , used ketchup instead of tomato paste since thats what other reviewrs suggested ... But still used 1 egg.

text:
I tried this recipe, and I must say that it's definitely the best meatloaf I've ever had to date hands down! You wouldn't even know that it's not beef... I followed the recipe to a T, except for a few things. 1) You definitely should use more than 1/4 a cup of quinoa. More like 1/2 a cup is perfect. For added flavor, I cooked the Quinoa in Unsalted Chicken Stock! 2) instead of that brown sugar sauce they say to put on top, I used a Honey Teryaki Glaze! 3) 55 minutes @ 350 degrees. Let it cool for 10 minutes and enjoy!

I have used this recipe to make meatballs. Instead of 2 eggs I use 1 egg, 1 egg white. I also add 2 TB. of grated Parmesan cheese and  chicken broth instead of H2O . I agree with using all dark meat or 1/2 and 1/2. for added moisture. (Half dark/half white.) For meatballs I cook them for 10 min. turn, then 10-15 min. more. You can use the meatballs for Swedish meatballs, Italian etc. Great for gluten free diets!
