userID:
5423874
Display Name:
mrouziek
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
77
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674141.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe for dinner tonight, and I made a few changes for taste -- I substituted a slightly spicy BBQ sauce for the hot sauce to give flavor without heat, and for the glaze I substituted whole grain mustard for half of the brown sugar to enhance the spice in the BBQ sauce without making it too sweet. I also added an extra egg to help it stick together better.

The recipe itself is very delicious, and it won over the whole family (including the picky eaters, young and old). Since I was baking it in an 8x8 pan I took care to drain the fat and juices a couple of times so that the loaf wouldn't come out mushy. However, I still managed to accidentally dump half of the loaf out into the sink when I drained the last bit of the juices. The result was that the dish wasn't too juicy, but it also still fell apart. In the future, I'm going to try variations with rolled oats or partially-cooked quinoa or uncooked quinoa to see if I can overcome the problem of the loaf falling apart in the pan.

Verdict: Great base recipe, definitely worth experimenting with.
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2013-10-15T18:09:10.53
helpfulCount:
0

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I loved making this receipe, I added some additonal ingredients on top of everything listed.. I did find that after mixing all the ingredients that it was very moist as noted in receipe and not easy to make into a loaf. In the the sautee pan with onion I added equal amounts of green pepper and fresh campari tomatoes. I also added a 1/2 teaspoon of fennel seed, fresh ground sea salt and black pepper. In the bowl with turkey I added 1 tsp of fresh thyme and an extra egg like one of the other reviews did. I also cubed up a small amount of goat cheese brie and mixed that in. I used ketchup instead of tomato paste. I used tapatio for pepper sauce. The only other thing I did was add 1 1/2 tbsp of ketchup in the sauce made for drizzling over the top.  I would recommend putting the loaf in a pan with edges as this has a lot of liquid.  I decided to cook my loaf in waterless cookware on the stove top for 30 mins instead of the oven. It came out perfect.The flavor was out of this world. By far the best meatloaf I have ever made. My sweetie said it was great. I will definitely be making this again.

text:
I only gave it 4 stars due to modifications based on previous reviews, but overall a very good recipe!  Based on the reviews, I only used 1/2 Tbs of Chipoltle Tabasco and used 1/2 Tbs of Chipoltle barbecue sauce due to not wanting it to be too hot for my parents.  Also based on previous reviews, I reduced the salt to 1 tsp.  Oh, for some smokiness, I added 1/2 a teaspoon of liquid smoke.  It seemed too moist, so I also added 3 teaspoons of bread crumbs.  The glaze was a little too sweet, so I think next time I will either do just ketchup or barbecue sauce on top.

This recipe was a hit with my hubby who is a major meatloaf fan, but isn't too wild about turkey meatloaf.  I made a few adjustments since I didn't have some of the ingredients.  I used A-1 steak sauce and soy sauce in place of Worcestershire, ketchup instead of tomato paste, mixed the onion and garlic right in without cooking first, stuck with old fashion ketchup for topping since I didn't have brown sugar, and used 2 eggs.  I even sent it for lunch with my 3 year old the next day.  The container came back empty.  My 2 year old on the other hand wouldn't touch it, but that's not saying much since he won't eat most things unless it's covered with breading.

This was amazing!!
Moist and flavorful and cooked to perfection easy peasy!!
I cut the hot sauce in half as other reviewers suggested and was glad I did, still had a bit of a kick but didn't overpower the AMAZING taste. It didn't need any kind of sauce or seasoning once cooked (although I used ketchup to draw 'laces' on my football shaped loaf and that was a nice little addition).
The recipe calls for 1.25 lbs of ground turkey, I used ground chicken because that's what I accidently grabbed from the store... I had to get 2 1lb packages but next time will just use 1lb and hopefully it will be just as good.
MMMmMMmMMmMmm!!!

text:
So delicious!  My husband said we should make this once a month at least.  We followed the recipe for the most part, with a few tweaks:
We added an extra egg like others recommended, and chopped up red bell pepper and sauteed with onion (step 3).  Also put about a tablespoon of grated Parmesan cheese over cooled onion/pepper mixture.  We used a little Frank's hot sauce since I can't take the heat.  Turned out amazing.
We served the meatloaf with smashed potatoes (Pinterest) and sauteed broccoli.

text:
AMAZING!!! Just made this tonight. Not only it is the best meatloaf I have ever made, it was the best meatloaf I have ever had! I did a couple very slight modifications. I added an extra egg, about a quarter cup to half a cup of breadcrumbs to bind the mixture, and instead of tomato paste I used ketchup as I noticed most people did that as well. My husband went back for seconds it was so good! The topping really added a burst of flavour. Even my 2 year old ate it, and it is difficult to get him to eat anything these days! Didn't seem to have any issues with this dish! I know he is getting the healthy quinoa and the turkey, so it made me feel good as a Mom! I found the meatloaf to be moist and didn't lack any taste in the least! It was bursting with flavour. I will make this over and over again, only difference is I would double the batch so we can eat more of it!!

text:
This was so amazing! I added fresh parsley, bell pepper, mushrooms and didnt have hot sauce so I used tiger sauce. Served it up atop pureed cauliflower and it was a true winner, even the baby loved it! I always have quinoa on hand for baby food and never buy bread crumbs which is why I chose this recipe. One reviewer mentioned it added no flavor and its not supposed to, it just acts as a binder and has more nutritional value than bread crumbs.

country:
None
text:
My new favorite meatloaf! I have had this recipe for over a year and was hesitant to try it because of the negative reviews.  I really struggled with how to procede: should I try the recipe as written which is my preference or heed the advice of reviewers?  I decided to try it as written and after reading several complaints about the amount of hot pepper sauce, I deceased the hot pepper sauce by half.  My young kids can't handle too much spice anyway.  This was the right choice for us.  I could still taste the hot pepper sauce but it didn't overpower.  I also used Frank's hot sauce which is milder than Tobassco and I can see how a full 2T. of Tobassco would make someone say "woo doggies!".  Anyway, we loved it!  Even my health-food averted husband said it was great.

text:
I loved this meatloaf! I used ground chicken instead of turkey and it was my first time cooking with quinoa. I followed the poster's suggestion and used 2 eggs and although I used a little extra chicken and onions, it was still too wet and mushy. I wasn't even able to form a loaf. Eventually I just added another 1/4 cup of quinoa and that helped. It was still mushy but I was able to form the loaf. I used Frank's Red Hot Buffalo Sauce because that was all I had. Next time I would add extra for more zing. I may also add a bit more spices but it is  fine as is. I cooked it a little longer so it was slightly brown on top and it turned our wonderfully. I prefer it to regular meatloaf. Thanks for posting Drew!

text:
I also used 2 eggs instead of one, and more like 1/2 cup of quinoa instead of 1/4 cup. Definitely needs to be molded on a flat cooking sheet rather than using a loaf pan as a previous reviewer wrote, because there are a LOT of fat drippings that would have made for a really gross mess in a loaf pan. I did make the glaze and thought it was perfect, although I would recommend making twice as much as described to really get the loaf covered with it. Loved the hot sauce ingredient, big fan of that. My husband loved this... Would recommend making double the recipe if cooking for more than 2-3 people. Tasted DELICIOUS!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This is literally the first time I have ever felt compelled to leave a review for a recipe.  I have made this 5 times now since originally downloading it.  It's a delicious recipe that served us well on this snowy evening.  Because I am sometimes a bit scattered I have come up with a couple of modifications for if you want to make this but have failed to buy onions:
1. Cut up one apple into 1 cm cubes and fry with the garlic. Add to recipe in place of onions.
2. Chop one 10 oz container of mushrooms, sautee for 5-10 minutes in olive oil till soft, add garlic and cook 2 mins, deglaze pan with balsamic or red wine vinegar. Add to recipe in place of onions.  This was a little lacking in moisture compared to the original recipe and the apple idea, room for improvement.
3. (Not onion related) I added some ginger poweder to the glaze, turned out well.

text:
This has become one of my favorite recipes. I used to make meatloaf about once a year (at the most!). This meatloaf is so tasty. The quinoa keeps it moist. I also use Frank's Red Hot Sauce instead of a spicy hot sauce which can be overpowering. Instead of brown sugar, I use two packets of Splenda to keep the calories/sugar down. I started a diet 3-1/2 months ago and was looking for a healthier way of cooking. Replacing ground turkey for beef I thought would be kind of tasteless but it isn't. Last night I made it with cauliflower/potato mash. Since I had leftover meatloaf and potatoes I made a shepherds pie with the leftovers. Normally I make a meatloaf parmesan which tastes like a giant meatball covered in reduced fat mozzarella and marinara. It also makes a great meatloaf sandwich. Try this recipe, you won't be disappointed.

text:
This meatloaf is great! I'm giving 4/5 stars for the original recipe because I think the hot pepper sauce and black pepper amounts need to be halved- the amount called for overwhelms the other flavors, I think. I'm making this again tonight with half of the amount called for and I expect it to be a 5 star recipe! Make sure to NOT use ground turkey breast- it is too dry. A lean, 93% fat free ground turkey does the trick without sacrificing the health benefits.

text:
3 stars as written, 5 stars with a few minor changes: no hot sauce, 2 eggs, and only 1/2 tsp salt. I also prefer a simple brown sugar/ketchup/mustard/Worcestershire blend for the glaze. I agree with some of the other reviewers that the hot sauce overwhelms the rest of the ingredients. Better to have it on the table to add as people want for their individual servings. Soo tasty without!!

text:
Adding to the family recipe book!  I rarely follow a recipe to the dot.  My variations include the following:  added 1 carrot, 3 green onions, 1 tomato all diced.  I like color and this added a more interesting look, texture and flavor.  I also mixed the Worcestershire and brown sugar in addition to the top.  Also, I broiled the loaf for a more appealing color.  I did not include the tomato paste.  I felt it didn't need it after I mixed the the sauce and sugar within.  Kids and hubby enjoyed it, so it was a win win!!!

text:
I really liked this recipe.  I have probably only made meatloaf a couple of times in my life because it always turns out like, well, a hunk of meat.  I love quinoa and am always looking for new ways to use it.  It gave this meatloaf a really great texture and broke up the "meatiness" of it.  
Very moist and flavorful too.  My only changes were that I used ketchup because I didn't have tomato paste, I threw in a little Italian seasoning, and omitted the salt.
I would definitely recommend this recipe!

I am often hesitant of turkey meatloaf recipes- but gave this one a try because I was intrigued by the use of quinoa.  This meatloaf is fantastic!  I love the use of quinoa in place of the usual breadcrumbs and appreciate the benefit of the added whole grains! This will be my go-to recipe for ground turkey from now on!

text:
Delicious, healthy supper!  Basically followed the recipe except a few minor changes.  First, I added more garlic than called for (3 cloves which was just right, not overpowering, but I do love my garlic!).  Second, used ketchup instead of tomato paste.  Third, I used Sriracha hot sauce for the hot pepper sauce.  Finally, I cooked the meat mixture in lightly greased muffin tins.  Recipe made 12 muffins which I cooked at 350 F for 30 minutes, plan on freezing the extras!

Awesome recipe!!!  I didn't have 20 oz of turkey, I had 2 16 oz packages so I used them both and changed the serving size to 8. Oh, and I followed the recipe exactly (apart from scaling to a new amount and using a convection oven)!

country:
None
text:
This had a great kick to it, and for those of you who are worried about the brown sugar topping, don't be.  It's sweet, but not overwhelmingly so, and you probably won't end up with a thick layer of it anyway.  The biggest problem with this for us was that it was a little dry.  This could be my fault; my one deviation from the recipe was that I used extra-lean ground turkey.  If I make it again, I'll use regular.  Still, the quinoa was an interesting idea, and one I'll probably try to adapt for other meatloaf recipes - thanks!

Loved it!  I added about a half green pepper diced, and 1 shredded carrot, plus 2/3 of the tomato paste can went in the bottom, and the rest mixed in with the topping.  I also UP'ed the amount of quinoa to 1/2 c. (with a cup of water) instead of 1/4.  This is my new favourite!.
